hydrotherapy: a focus on contrast water therapy
description: Theories behind the therapeutic use of contrast baths –Contrast baths lead to a slight rise in skin temperature, thus improving circulation in a treated extremity and, to a lesser extent, in the contralateral extremity(1) –Contrast baths are believed to lead to a vascular pumping action due to cyclical vasoconstriction (cold water) and vasodilation (hot water)(1) –Contrast baths may reduce sensation, thus reducing painful sensations and improving mobility
Clinicians are cautioned about the use of contrast baths and contrast water therapy. The theories listed above have yet to be substantiated

other: Clinicians should follow the guidelines of their clinic/hospital and what is ordered by the patient’s physician. The summary below is meant to serve as a guide, not to replace orders from a physician or a clinic’s specific protocols

Patients being treated with contrast baths may have a condition that places them at risk for falls; follow facility protocols for fall prevention and post fall-prevention instructions at bedside, if inpatient. Ensure that patient and family/caregivers are aware of the potential for falls and educated about fall-prevention  strategies. Discharge criteria should include independence with fall-prevention  strategies ›Diagnosis/need for device/equipment: There are multiple indications for contrast baths; please see Indications for device/ equipment, above

other considerations: Blood flow studies –Contrast baths induce transient changes in hemodynamics and oxygenation levels of muscular tissue which may benefit tissue repair(3) -Based on a study in Canada in which10 healthy men and women averaging 29 years of age participated -Contrast bath therapy was provided for the left lower leg of the participants -Contrast bath protocol included a 10 minute baseline, 30 minutes of contrast bath with a hot:cold ratio of 4:1, and 10 minutes of recovery -The gastrocnemius muscle was monitored for oxygenation (O2Hb), deoxygenation (HHb), total hemoglobin (tHb), and tissue saturation index (TSI%) during the protocol -Noted outcomes included increased level of intramuscular oxygenated blood volume in the gastrocnemius muscle post 30 minutes of contrast bath  –Authors concluded that increased oxygenated blood flow may assist in tissue repair; however, further research is warranted to determine the effects of contrast baths in persons with acute and chronic muscle damage and soreness
treatment summary: At this time, the available research on the efficacy of contrast baths is poor in overall quality and RCTs with solid methodology on the use of contrast baths are lacking(1)

Based on a systematic review and meta-analysis,  cold water immersion and contrast water therapy is beneficial for perception of fatigue, when applied at 72 hours and 24 hours post sport, respectively. Neither improved perceptions of muscle soreness following team sport(2)

Contrast water therapy and cold water therapy do not improve short-term  recovery post resistance training(4) –Thirteen men were assessed for fatigue, soreness, maximal voluntary isometric contraction, weighted/unweighted jumps post resistance training. Training included maximal voluntary isometric contraction of the knee extensors and weighted and unweighted countermovement jumps. Subjects participated in one of three 14-minute  recovery strategies post exercise: contrast water therapy, cold-water  immersion, or a control –Countermovement jump performance and peak torque during maximal voluntary contraction were significantly decreased for at least 4 hours post exercise –The authors concluded that neither contrast water therapy nor cold-water  immersion improves short-term  recovery post resistance training

Researchers investigated the effects of time ratios and the order of hot/cold application with contrast baths for patients with plantar fasciitis and concluded that no time ratio or order of hot/cold is superior to another(5) –Seventy-five  patients were randomized into three groups in which different ratios and order of hot/cold application for contrast baths were used -Group A – 3 cycles of 3 minutes hot followed by 1 minute cold -Group B – 3 minutes hot, 1 minute cold, 12 minutes hot -Group C – 5 minutes cold, 2.5 minutes hot, 5 minutes cold –Participants in all groups also took part in a simple protocol which included education for shoe wear and plantar fascia and tendo-achilles  stretching exercises –The authors concluded that no ratio or order for hot/cold in contrast baths is superior to another; contrast baths used with a simple plantar fascia protocol result in significant pain relief ›See Description , Indications of device/equipment , and Guidelines for use of device/equipment,  above .
